CHAPLAIN'S RKPOKT
Sin: I have the honor to submit herewith my biennial report is chaplain of the penitentiary.
In the first place let me express to you and to Deputy Warden Welch, and the various officers connected with the institution.
my grateful thanks for the many kindnesses received at your bands. My age. and sickness during the last year, have prevented me from giving that continued personal attention to the work that I have done in the past and that I would like to do now. but your kindness through these trying times has been
ising and has tended greatly to relieve me from worry in
iftlictiou.
So far as I am able to judge, the moral tone of the institution s been excellent. The discipline has been firm but kindly, and e men have shown by their conduct that they appreciate the
treatment they have received. Very few complaints have reached me, but on the contrary many of the men. both in the prison and after their release, have expressed their appreciation of the way in which the institution is conducted.
Religious services have been held each Sunday during the ntire two years, either by myself or by ministers and others
who have kindly taken my place when I could not be present. Tlie Sunday school work luis also been continued regularly
during the entire time by volunteer teachers from outside. Among those who have been especially active and faithful in
work are Miss Kingman. Mr. Hoge. Mrs. Evans. Mr. Ober
. Mrs. Hall and others. Mr. Oberlies has also kindly given hi.s vices during the last few months as leader of the choir, in
which position he has proved himself very efficient. The Chrisi'mil Scientists have had a class during the past year, and Catholic services have been held about once a month during most of
still continue The bel

those prisoners whose early educational advantage* were limired might be taught to read and write, and such other branches as would fit them better for the duties of life when they go out. This of course needs legislative sanction, but I think it a reform that should receive the careful consideration of our lawmakers.
I am also of the opinion that there should be a change in, the clothing of the prisoners so that stripes would no longer be the usual garb, but only worn as punishment for disorderly conduct while in the institution. This is in accordance with the reforms being introduced in the bt-si managed penal institutions, ami
where tried has been found to work very satisfactorily
I have the honor to remain your obedient servant
P. \V. H..

Lancaster. Neb., December 1. 1900.
Hon. John H. Hopkins. Warden Nebraska Stare Penitentiary:

Nebraska State Penitentiary for the biennial period closing No-
vember 30, 1900. together with such recommendations as I .leem
for the good of the prison.
